Today, it is very important to develop energy conversion devices such as fuel cells in order to meet the demand for clean energy. In fuel cells, on the other hand, nanostructures are frequently used. To benefit from this activity, the dendritic semi-hexagonal Pt@PdS2-MWCNT catalyst was synthesized using the hydrothermal method within the scope of the study. According to XRD results, it was determined that the crystal structure of Pt@PdS2-MWCNT was formed, and it had a crystal size of 4.11 nm. In addition, because of TEM studies, it was observed that there were particles of 4.02 nm on the MWCNT surface and a Quasihexagonal structure was obtained. The resulting catalyst was used in fuel cell application as an anodic catalyst for the oxidation of methanol, 2-propanol, and glycerol. The catalyst synthesized in the results obtained; Current peaks of 86.71 mA/cm2, 67.32 mA/cm2 and 58.44 mA/cm2 were obtained in cyclic voltammetry for methanol, 2-propanol, and glycerol, respectively. At the same time, scanning speed, chronoamperometry and long-term stability tests were performed for electro-oxidation stability and stability of the catalyst for methanol, 2-propanol and glycerol oxidations using sulfuric acid buffer solution. The results provided better stability and activity of the catalyst, with a higher current peak and 11.7% retention for methanol oxidation compared to other alcohols. Graphical Abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Alcohol oxidation Fuel cell Energy Quasihexagonal structure Electrocatalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Fossil fuels are the most used sources in energy production, but they also have a negative impact on the environment [1]. Increasing energy demand due to the increasing population increases the interest in alternative and environmental energy systems [2,3]. Fuel cells are recognized as an efficient alternative for this energy demand [4]. These systems are environmentally friendly energy devices that convert the chemical energy of fuels into electricity, water and heat [5,6]. Fuels used for fuel cells can vary and alcohol-based fuels offer high potential in application [7]. Alcohol-based fuels are liquid at ambient temperatures, are an excellent energy source, and show a higher volumetric energy density than hydrogen [8]. Direct alcohol fuel cells offer advantages such as effortless storage, small size, easy handling, low operating temperature, and superior energy density [9]. Methanol is mostly used as fuel in alcohol fuel cells [10]. Today, methanol is frequently used directly in alcohol fuel cells due to its high energy density, renewable, cheap, and accessibility. The fuel used in another alcohol fuel cell, such as methanol, is 2-propanol and glycerol. The fact that this fuel, 2-propanol, and glycerol with different carbon numbers, theoretically has high energy, shows that it can be used directly in alcohol fuel cells [11]. Energy is released as a result of redox reactions in alcohol fuel cells. According to this; Alcohol oxidation in alcohol fuel cells is an electrochemical reaction that occurs at the anode of the cell [12]. Certain catalysts are used for these reactions to take place. Low-efficiency and high-cost catalysts make the commercialization of fuel cells difficult. However, as the anode catalyst with the highest reaction efficiency, platinum (Pt) is still the most preferred material [13]. The high cost of Pt and its CO poisoning in fuel cells has led to the search for different catalysts. At the same time, the toxic reaction of Pt shortens the life of the fuel cell [14]. Nanomaterials showed powerful activity on different major of engineering such as sensor [15–18], energy [19–22], food safety [23,24], catalyst [25–28], biomedical [29,30], water treatment [31–35] and etc. Catalyst studies are carried out by obtaining bimetallic nano-structures with elements such as Pd, Ru, Co, Au, Ag, S, Fe, and Ni in order to reduce these negative effects and increase the electrocatalytic activity [36–38]. One of the most preferred among them is Pd. Pd-based electrocatalysts have recently attracted attention in fuel cell applications. However, it has been reported that there is still an alloying with a second transition metal for the development of Pd catalysts due to the weak activity and rapid destabilization of Pd catalysts [39]. At the same time, it is noteworthy that carbon-based nanomaterials with low cost and high surface area are used to reduce the cost of Pt-based fuel cells and provide high performance [5]. CNTs from carbon-based nanomaterials, unique electrical and structural properties, excellent flexibility, and high surface area make them viable candidates for alcohol electrooxidation [40]. At the same time, inorganic oxide additives in CNTs increase the performance of electrolytes in fuel cells [41]. At this point, within the scope of the study, it was aimed to create high electron transfer by utilizing the superior properties of the multi-walled carbon nanotube (MWCNT) material and was used for the synthesis of catalysts with high electrochemical performance [42]. In this study, to see the effect of nanostructures on alcohol oxidation, Pt@PdS2-MWCNT quasihexagonal nanostructures were obtained. Nanostructure, crystal, and morphological structures were analyzed. Alcohol oxidation studies were carried out on different alcohol types with the obtained structure. It was seen that the Pt@PdS2-MWCNT catalyst obtained as a result of the studies gave successful results for all three alcohol oxidations used. 2 Materials and method 2.1 Chemicals Palladium chloride (PdCl2, 99,9%), MWCNT (98%), thiourea (%99), ethanol (99,9%), methanol (99,9%), 2-propanol (99,5%), glycerol (88%), platinum chloride (PtCl4, 96%), F-127 pluronic, ascorbic acid (99%), sulfuric acid (H2SO4, 97%), Nafion D-521 solution (5%) and Dimethylformamide (DMF, 99%) chemicals It was used in Pt@PdS2-MWCNT synthesis and alcohol oxidation studies. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis 2.2.1 Synthesis of PdS2-MWCNT At the beginning of the study, firstly, the synthesis stages were made. 30 mg of MWCNT was added into 30 ml of dH2O and sonicated for 1 hour. In a separate beaker, 7 × 10−3 M PdCl2 and 15 × 10−3 M thiourea were added into 15 ml of dH2O and mixed for 2 hours on a magnetic stirrer. The resulting solution was added to the dispersed MWCNT and stirred for 3 hours on a magnetic stirrer. The resulting mixture was added to a 100 ml Teflon-lined autoclave system and kept at 180°C for 24 hours. After the resulting mixture was cooled to room temperature, it was collected at 5000 rpm for 15 minutes and washed several times with dH2O-ethanol (50% v/v) to remove impurities. The PdS2-MWCNT pellet was dried in an oven at 50°C in the atmospheric environment. After this step, Pt@PdS2-MWCNT synthesis was made. 2.2.2 Synthesis of Pt@ PdS2-MWCNT Pt@PdS2-MWCNT was synthesized using the chemical reflux method. 30 mg of PdS2-MWCNT was added to 30 ml of dH2O and stirred for 1 hour in a magnetic stirrer. 24 × 10−3 M PtCl4 and 30 mg of F-127 pluronic were added to 7.5 ml of dH2O and dissolved in a magnetic stirrer for 1 hour. Then, the mixture was added to the PdS2-MWCNT solution and stirred on a magnetic stirrer for 3 hours. 7.5 ml of 0.1 M ascorbic acid was added to the mixture and the mixture was refluxed at 95°C for 18 hours in a water-cooled system. Finally, the mixture was collected by centrifugation at 5000 rpm for 15 minutes and washed with dH2O-ethanol (50% v/v). Pt@PdS2-MWCNT pellet was dried in an oven at 50°C in the atmospheric environment. After the synthesis processes, the material characterization processes were carried out. 2.3 Characterization of Pt@PdS2-MWCNT NPs The crystal structure of Pt@PdS2-MWCNT nanoparticles was determined using X-Ray Crystallography (XRD) Cu Kα radiation (Rigaku MiniFlex, Türkiye), and morphological properties were made using Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) (JEM-2100 Plus- Türkiye). Electrochemical alcohol oxidation studies of Pt@PdS2-MWCNT NPs, cyclic voltammetry (CV), and scan rate (SR) methods were examined by using a potentiostat galvanostat (Gamry Interface 3000-Türkiye) device. The stability test of the obtained catalyst was carried out using 100 cycles (CV) and 1000 seconds chronoamperometry measurements. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Structural and morphological studies After synthesizing Pt@PdS2-MWCNT nanoparticles, crystal structure and morphological structure analyzes were performed. Diffractogram analysis of synthesized Pt@PdS2-MWCNT nanoparticles was performed using the XRD method. Fig. 1 gives the XRD graph of the synthesized material. According to the XRD results, it was calculated that the crystal structure of Pt@PdS2-MWCNT was formed and had a crystalline size of 4.11 nm. Furthermore, because of TEM studies, it was seen that there were particles of 4.02 nm on the MWCNT surface and the Quasihexagonal structure was obtained. The flat apex between 23-28° (2θ) indicates the (001) plane of C. The exact peaks of the Face-Centered Cubic (FCC) crystal structure are seen at 40.43°, 46.95°, 68.29°, 81.98°, and 89.51° (2θ). These peaks, respectively, show the planes (111), (200), (220), (311), and (222) of the Pt crystal structure [43]. When the XRD result is compared with the Crystallographic database (COD) number 9008480; It was observed that the sharp peaks of Pt shifted to the right concerning the reference sample. The formation of the Pt@PdS2-MWCNT structure is explained by the mismatch arrangement of Pd atoms in Pt-based bimetallic catalysts, and the shift in the d-band center in the crystal structure of Pt [44]. The crystal size of Pt@PdS2-MWCNT nanoparticles was calculated as 4.11 nm according to the Scherrer equation. Analysis of Pt@PdS2-MWCNT nanoparticles was performed using TEM. As a result of the analysis, it was observed that dendritic structures were formed in a Quasihexagonal shape (Fig. 2 a-b). Quasihexagonal structures have been measured to be approximately 140 nm in size. MWCNTs form more high surface area by staying under Quasihexagonal structures. Some Pt ​​nanostructures appear to be deposited on the MWCNT surface (Fig. 2c). The size of nanoparticles present on the MWCNT surface has a particle size of about 4.02 nm. The Pt@PdS2-MWCNT structure obtained in quasihexagonal structure, large surface area, and dendritic structure cause it to have high catalytic active surfaces. In this way, it is expected that the catalyst will show high activity in alcohol oxidation studies. 3.2 Studies for the oxidation of different alcohols Electrocatalytic measurements of Pt@PdS2-MWCNT nanoparticles were made using a potentiostat galvanostat. The measurements were carried out using a glassy carbon electrode (GCE), silver/silver chloride, and the platinum electrode at room temperature with a triple electrode system in a 0.5 M H2SO4 environment under a nitrogen atmosphere. The alcohol oxidation catalyst was prepared by sonicating 10 mg of Pt@PdS2-MWCNT powder with 500 μL dH2O, 75 μL Nafion D- 521 (5%), and 150 μL DMF for 30 min. The prepared catalyst is used after dripping on GCE and dried. CV, SR, and CR measurements were performed with the prepared system Potantiostat device. CR stability measurements were made at 1000s in 0.5 M H2SO4 buffer solution. CV measurements were performed at a scanning rate of 50mV/s -1 between -0.2 and 1 V and electro-oxidation studies were performed for 1 M methanol (CH3OH), 1 M 2-propanol (C3H8O), and 1 M glycerol (C3H8O3) of the catalyst obtained. In Fig. 3 , electro-oxidation studies were performed for 1 M CH3OH, 1 M C3H8O, and 1 M C3H8O3 using Pt@PdS2-MWCNT catalyst in a 0.5 M H2SO4 environment. The comparative results of alcohol oxidation electrochemical measurements obtained in different types of alcohol are given Fig. 3a shows the CV curves for three alcohols using the Pt@PdS2-MWCNT catalyst at a scanning rate of 50mV/s. CV is a widely used technique to study the oxidation and reduction processes of molecular species [45]. The resulting catalyst was found to provide high electrochemical performance for all three alcohols used. The results showed two well-defined peaks during forward and backward screening for MOR at three alcohol streams. As seen in Fig. 3b, the highest current density was obtained in CH3OH oxidation with an oxidation flow peak of 86.71 mA/cm2 at the peaks obtained, then the lowest current density was obtained in C3H8O with a current peak of 67.32 mA/cm2 and the lowest current density was obtained in C3H8O3 oxidation with 58.44 mA/cm2. Compared to other alcohols, the resulting catalyst showed higher and improved activity in CH3OH oxidation. In CV analysis, it is reported that backward peaks (Ib) are related to poisoning tolerance and the ability of the catalyst to oxidize absorbed active intermediates [46]. The high If/Ib ratio reflects intoxication tolerance and high electrocatalytic activity [39]. At this point, the calculated If/Ib ratios for the three alcohols are given in Table 1 . Looking at Table 1, although the highest current density is obtained in CH3OH oxidation, it is seen that other alcohols have higher If/Ib values. This can be attributed to the fact that the catalyst has less tolerance to poisoning in CH3OH oxidation. When the studies are examined, it is reported that C3H8O3 shows better poisoning tolerance in an alkaline environment [46]. Within the scope of the study, it can be said that working in an acid environment also affects the poisoning tolerance in C3H8O3 oxidation. It seems that the greatest poisoning tolerance of the catalyst occurs in the oxidation of glycerol. In addition, the LSV responses shown in Figs. 3c and 3d show that the initial potential for C3H8O is 0.018 V, 0.089 V for CH3OH, and 0.353 V for C3H8O3. In Fig. 2e, CR measurements of the long-term stability (at 0.55 s 0.55V) of the Pt@PdS2-MWCNT catalyst in different alcohols in a buffer solution of 0.5 M H2SO4 at 0.55 V are given. When the CR results were examined, it was observed that the current density decreased over time when the Pt@PdS2-MWCNT catalyst worked more stably in the CH3OH environment. This can be explained by the fact that fewer intermediate products are produced in CH3OH during electro-oxidation. In C3H8O and C3H8O3 alcohols, more intermediates cause sudden current drops, preventing the catalyst from remaining stable for a long time. The dendritic quasihexagonal structure of the Pt@PdS2-MWCNT catalyst provides a high surface area and provides the long-term catalytic activity. At this point, the performance of the catalyst in terms of stability for different alcohols is examined. The stability of the catalyst can be examined by the ratio of the final current density (Jf) obtained for each type of alcohol to the initial current (Ji). In Table 2 , the initial and final current densities are given. The final current densities (Jf) for CH3OH, C3H8O, and C3H8O3 were found to be 12.95, 11.68, and 6.12 mA/cm2, respectively. The Jf/Ji ratios obtained are 0.117, 0.105 and 0.065 mA/cm2, respectively. These results showed that the catalyst showed the best stability for methanol at a rate of 11.7% compared to other alcohols. The results also show that CR and CV analyses are compatible. 3.3 Methanol oxidation studies Shown below; When the reactions that take place in DMFCs are examined; oxygen at the cathode is reduced to water at the anode, and methanol is oxidized to CO2 [47]. (1) C H 3 OH + H 2 O → C O 2 + 6 H + + 6 e − ( anode reaction ) (2) 1.5 O 2 + 6 H + + 6 e − → 3 H 2 O ( cathode reaction ) (3) C H 3 OH + 1.5 O 2 → C O 2 + 2 H 2 O ( total reaction ) Using the Pt@PdS2-MWCNT catalyst, CH3OH oxidation performance at different scan rates and cycle numbers was examined. Measurements were taken in 0.5 M H2SO4 solution SR (50-300 mv/s) and 100 CV scanning. Fig. 4 a shows the SR results. The results showed an increase in current values due to the increased scanning speed. It has been observed that anodic current peak flow points shift towards positive values. The reason for the shift is due to the intermediate products formed as a result of oxidation studies [47]. The results obtained showed that the relationship between the square root and peak currents of the scanning rate was a highly surface-controlled electrode, as shown in Fig. 4b [48]. It was also performed by measuring 100 CV to assess the long-term stability of CH3OH oxidation, and cycles 1st and 100th are shown in Fig. 4c. Towards the 100th cycle, there was an increase in peak flow points. Approximately 5.5 times more current value was obtained due to the fact that the intermediates formed as a result of 100 cycles could not fully cover the catalyst active surface. While the forward peak flow point shifted to the right due to the intermediate products formed, an increase occurred at the reverse current peak. Long-term 100 cycle measurements support CR results for CH3OH. 3.4 Glycerol oxidation electrochemical studies C3H8O3 is cheap renewable, affordable, flammable, and non-volatile, making it an easily usable alternative fuel in fuel cells [49]. Studies have found that the oxidation activity of glycerol depends on the catalyst, pH, O2 pressure, and glycerol: catalyst ratio [50]. Within the scope of the study, oxidation activity in the presence of 1M C3H8O3 in an acid medium was examined. The reaction that occurs directly in C3H8O3 fuel cells is shown below [46]: (4) C 3 H 8 O 3 + 3 H 2 O → 3 C O 2 + 14 H + + 14 e − ( anode reaction ) (5) 3 / 2 O 2 + 6 H + + 6 e − → 3 H 2 O ( cathode reaction ) (6) C 3 H 8 O 3 + 7 / 2 O 2 → 3 C O 2 + 4 H 2 O ( total reaction ) These reactions play an important role in the performance of alcohol fuel cells. Using the Pt@PdS2-MWCNT catalyst, the oxidation performance of C3H8O3 at different scan rates and cycle counts was examined as in the studies for CH3OH. The measurements were scanned with a Scan Rate (50-300 mv/s) and 100 CV in 0.5 M H2SO4 solution. Fig. 5 a shows the Scan Rate results. The results showed an increase in current values due to the increased scanning speed. It has been observed that anodic current peak flow points shift towards positive values. The reason for the shift is due to the intermediate products formed as a result of oxidation studies [47]. The results obtained showed that the relationship between the square root and peak currents of the scanning rate was a highly surface-controlled electrode, as shown in Fig. 5b [48]. It was also performed by measuring 100 CVs to assess the long-term stability of C3H8O3 oxidation, and cycles 1st and 100th are shown in Fig. 5c. Towards the 100th cycle, there was an increase in peak flow points. Approximately 4 times more current value was obtained because the intermediates formed as a result of 100 cycles could not fully cover the active surface of the catalyst. While the forward peak flow point shifted to the right due to the intermediate products formed, an increase occurred at the reverse current peak. Long-term measurements of 100 cycles support CR results for C3H8O3. The fact that C3H8O3 has a higher carbon count than CH3OH has caused it to be more affected by by-products formed as a result of alcohol oxidation, causing it to show lower stability. 3.5 2- propanol oxidation electrochemical studies 2-Propanol is flammable and is a colorless organic compound. 2-Propanol oxidation is similar to other methanol and ethanol oxidations and consists of two oxidative current peaks, forward CV scan, and backward CV scan. In the equations shown below for 2-propanol, it has been reported that acetone is formed as an intermediate, which can act as a catalyst poison [51]. (7) ( C H 3 ) 2 CHOH + 2 O H − → ( C H 3 ) 2 CO + 2 H 2 O + 2 e − ( anode reaction ) (8) ( C H 3 ) 2 CO + 16 O H − → 3 C O 2 + 11 H 2 O + 16 e − ( cathode reaction ) (9) ( C H 3 ) 2 CHOH + 18 O H − → 3 C O 2 + 18 e − + 13 H 2 O ( total reaction ) These reactions play an important role in the performance of alcohol fuel cells. Using the Pt@PdS2-MWCNT catalyst, the oxidation performance of C3H8O at different scanning rates and cycle numbers was investigated as in the studies for C3H8O3 and CH3OH. Measurements were made in 0.5 M H2SO4 solution at Scan Rate (50-300 mv/s) and 100 CV scans. Fig. 5a shows the Scan Rate results. The results showed that the current values ​​increased due to the increased scanning speed. It was observed that the anodic peak current points shifted towards positive values. The reason for the slip is due to the intermediate products formed as a result of oxidation studies [47]. The results obtained showed that the relationship between the square root of the scan rate and the peak currents is a highly surface controlled electrode, as shown in Fig. 5b. At the same time, to evaluate the long-term stability in C3H8O oxidation, a measurement of 100 CV was carried out, the 1st and 100th cycles are shown in Fig. 5c. There was an increase in peak flow points towards the 100th cycle. Since the intermediate products formed as a result of 100 cycles could not completely cover the catalyst active surface, approximately 1.5 times more current value was obtained. While the forward peak flow point shifted to the right due to the intermediate products, an increase occurred in the reverse flow peak. Long-term 100 cycles measurements support CR results for C3H8O. The fact that C3H8O has a higher carbon number than CH3OH has been affected more by the by-products of alcohol oxidation, causing it to show lower stability. As a result of alcohol oxidation opening with CH3OH, C3H8O, and C3H8O3 alcohols using Pt@PdS2-MWCNT catalyst, it has been shown that the catalyst works successfully in alcohols with different carbon content. Table 3 shows the comparison of alcohol oxidation studies using Pt@PdS2-MWCNT with the literature. 4 Conclusion Within the scope of the study, it was determined by TEM and XRD analyses that dendritic quasihexagonal Pt@PdS2-MWCNT nanoparticles were formed using the hydrothermal method. The synthesized catalyst was examined for the oxidations of CH3OH, C3H8O, and C3H8O3 in 0.5 M H2SO4 using the CV method at 0.55V and peak currents of 86.71 mA/cm2, 67.32 mA/cm2, and 58.44 mA/cm2 were observed, respectively. Scanning speeds and long-term stability tests showed that quasihexagonal Pt@PdS2-MWCNT catalyst showed greater stability in CH3OH oxidation than C3H8O and C3H8O3 alcohols. As a result of the study, it was seen that Pt@PdS2-MWCNT in quasihexagonal structure gave successful results in different types of alcohol oxidation and remained stable for a long time. It is thought that the results obtained in the study will lead to long-term stability and continuous efficiency studies, which are the biggest problems of fuel cells. coredata.dc:description: Today, it is very important to develop energy conversion devices such as fuel cells in order to meet the demand for clean energy. In fuel cells, on the other hand, nanostructures are frequently used. To benefit from this activity, the dendritic semi-hexagonal Pt@PdS2-MWCNT catalyst was synthesized using the hydrothermal method within the scope of the study. According to XRD results, it was determined that the crystal structure of Pt@PdS2-MWCNT was formed, and it had a crystal size of 4.11 nm. In addition, because of TEM studies, it was observed that there were particles of 4.02 nm on the MWCNT surface and a Quasihexagonal structure was obtained. The resulting catalyst was used in fuel cell application as an anodic catalyst for the oxidation of methanol, 2-propanol, and glycerol. The catalyst synthesized in the results obtained; Current peaks of 86.71 mA/cm2, 67.32 mA/cm2 and 58.44 mA/cm2 were obtained in cyclic voltammetry for methanol, 2-propanol, and glycerol, respectively. At the same time, scanning speed, chronoamperometry and long-term stability tests were performed for electro-oxidation stability and stability of the catalyst for methanol, 2-propanol and glycerol oxidations using sulfuric acid buffer solution. The results provided better stability and activity of the catalyst, with a higher current peak and 11.7% retention for methanol oxidation compared to other alcohols.
coredata.dc:title: Application of Quasihexagonal Pt@PdS2-MWCNT catalyst with High Electrochemical Performance for Electro-Oxidation of Methanol, 2-Propanol, and Glycerol Alcohols For Fuel Cells
